explanation: OS_TranslatePath: The function writes into the local_path buffer. To determine whether any standard string.h calls inside it can write past local_path (violating the rule) we must inspect its implementation and how it copies/truncates the incoming path. OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN: The size of local_path is the key bound used to check for out-of-bounds string operations; the exact numeric value or definition is required. OS_strnlen: OS_TranslatePath calls this wrapper; its semantics/implementation determine how lengths are measured and whether bounding logic is correct. OS_DirRemove_Impl: Although called only after translation, its prototype/behavior is needed to confirm it does not modify the passed buffer or expect a different string layout (e.g., write into the buffer) which could affect bounds safety. OS_SUCCESS: Needed to understand the control flow (when the buffer is used) and to know which code paths require the safety guarantees. Standard string.h functions (strncpy, strcpy, strlen, strncat, memcpy, memmove): To check MISRA compliance you must inspect any usage of these standard functions (or similar) in OS_TranslatePath and any downstream callees; include their occurrences/implementations/usages so you can verify correct length/bounds arguments and that no access beyond object bounds can occur.
